content.description: Climb crimps and sidepulls, and emerge onto a slabby section on Jiminy Cricket.
content.protection: Trees for an anchor at the top.
content.location: Find a square jug in a triangle cutout, stand under it, and take a step to the left.

content.description: Climb to the right of Eye Wash up a fissure.
content.protection: Trees for anchors at the top.
content.location: This ascends an obvious, wide fissure.

content.description: Snap, Crackle, Pop climbs nice holds revealed with cleaning a section where moss and lichen were more abundant.
content.protection: Trees for an anchor at the top.
content.location: Stand under two fissures starting a "V" at about the top of the bottom quarter of the wall (the lines do not complete the convergence into bottom of "V").Around mid-section of wall, stay to right of rounded diagonal, which rises to become vertical on the right, off the route.  The route ends soon after with the mantel from Gangnam Style, after which climbers can continue on either that route or Jiminy Cricket.

content.description: There is not much opportunity for hand or foot jams....
content.protection: Trees for an anchor at the top.
content.location: It ascends an obvious corner on the right end of the crag.

content.description: A square jug and a flare provide good hand holds.
content.protection: Trees for anchors at the top.
content.location: The start is under a protruding strip with a square jug.

content.description: This was named after FA grunts reminiscent of Op, Op, Op, Op in song Gangnam Style by PSY....It stays off corner features to the right and diagonal features at the bottom on the left.There are some good crimps. Aim for a mantel, and from there, continue a bit further up rather than merging left into Jiminy Cricket.
content.protection: Trees at the top for an anchor.
content.location: This route ascends the left side of the corner on the right side of the crag.

content.description: Eye Wash ascends crimpy, small hand holds but uses good foot holds.
content.location: It is left of Stairway to Heaven.

content.description: Cheers Rock has quick access from nearby Reservoir and Skyline trails on either side and a short walk from nearby parking lots. Parking lots often near or at capacity with dog walkers and other visitors, together with lot opening hours impacting ease of access.Really, nobody has ever climbed here? It seems likely that many undocumented ascents....Lichen and moss abound on the rock, almost as much as the broken glass on the ground that inspired the "Cheers" moniker.The bottom section has roped route opportunities, and there is bouldering on the upper left section as well as around the corner on right side of crag.There are sharp angles with crimps and some slopers and the occasional jug. Well-defined footholds are common.The rock is metabasalt hornfels and recrystallized metabasalt with porphyroblasts according to:Ridge, J.C., 2020 in progress, The Bedrock Geology of the Middlesex Fells Reservation (version: May 17, 2020)http://sites.tufts.edu/fellsgeology/.
